data.text: Say if thou knowest the time of the bringing forth of the wild goats of the rock,
And if thou hast numbered the full months of their being with young,
And hast reared their young without fear;
Their young will break forth; they will be multiplied with offspring:
And who is he that sent forth the wild ass free?
Whereas I made his habitation the wilderness,
He laughs to scorn the multitude of the city,
He will survey the mountains as his pasture,
And will the unicorn be willing to serve thee,
And wilt thou bind his yoke with thongs,
And dost thou trust him, because his strength is great?
And wilt thou believe that he will return to thee thy seed,
The peacock has a beautiful wing:
For the ostrich will leave her eggs in the ground,
And has forgotten that the foot will scatter them,
She has hardened herself against her young ones, as though she bereaved not herself:
For God has withholden wisdom from her,
In her season she will lift herself on high;
Hast thou invested the horse with strength,
And hast thou clad him in perfect armor,
He paws exulting in the plain,
He laughs to scorn a king as he meets him,
The bow and sword resound against him;
And he will not believe until the trumpet sounds.
And when the trumpet sounds, he says, Aha!
And does the hawk remain steady by thy wisdom,
And does the eagle rise at thy command,
On a crag of a rock, and in a secret place?
Thence he seeks food,
And his young ones roll themselves in blood,
